Description: Whether there are non-monetary restrictions on accessing an online service.
Relevant command, command-line fragment, or option for executing this function/running the tool in this mode.

Component dependency requirements for application. This includes runtime environments and shared libraries that are not included in the application distribution package, but required to run the application (examples: DirectX, Java or .NET runtime).
Monetary cost of acquiring the software.
The date indicating when the tool's entry was most recently modified or updated, providing a timestamp of the latest changes made to the tool's information.
Textual description of the tool.
Examples: This is a Python tool that ...

Description: Comment about the documentation.
Examples: "This software comes with comprehensive user manuals and FAQs to assist in navigation and troubleshooting. Regular updates to the documentation are provided based on software upgrades."

Description: Type of documentation that is linked to. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Link to documentation on the web for the tool.
Comment about the download.
Examples: "Before downloading this tool, ensure your device has adequate storage space and meets the minimum system requirements. Also, our tools may require specific software or apps to function properly. Please refer to our website for detailed information about the required software."

Description: The type of data, information, or system that is obtained when the link is resolved.
Link to download (or repo providing a download) for the software.
Version information (typically a version number) of the software applicable to this download.
Name of the entities that may be credited
Role performed by entity that is credited, e.g. “Developer”
Types of entities that may be credited, e.g. ‘Person’.
Concise comment about this function, if not apparent from the software description and EDAM annotations.
Examples: The tool is used to programmatically ...

Description: Grant number associated with the tool's development. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Homepage of the software, or some URL that best serves this purpose.
Type of primary input data. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Allowed format(s) of the input data. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Name of programming language the software source code was written in. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Software or data usage license. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Comment about the link.
Examples: "This tool cannot be accessed without a valid institutional login."

Description: The type of data, information or system that is obtained when the link is resolved. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
A link of some relevance to the software (URL).
Canonical tool name provided by the tool developer or service provider.
The operating system supported by a downloadable software package. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
The basic operation(s) performed by this software function. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Type of primary output data. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Allowed format(s) of the output data. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.

Specifies the software libraries, frameworks, or other components that a tool or package relies on for its proper functioning. This attribute helps users understand the prerequisites needed for installation and usage of the tool within a given computational environment
Examples: Python 3.7 or above, Django 2.2 or above, Postgresql 12.0 or above.

Description: Indicates whether the required package dependencies for tool are present.
Grant number associated with the tool's development. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
The pubMed identifer associated with the development of the tool.
The release date of a product or product model. This can be used to distinguish the exact variant of a product.
General scientific domain the software serves, or other general category. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
A type of application software: a discrete software entity can have more than one type. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Version information (typically a version number) of the software applicable to this entry.
The denormalized manifest for tool submission.
Examples: In a software interface, the 'Tool View' attribute might be set to "Detail View" or "Thumbnail View".

Description: A unique primary key that enables record updates using schematic.
